Description.val:
POLLUTION CONTROL SYSTEMS/EQUIPMENT:  This item provides funds for the procurement of pollution control systems and equipment that are required by Navy ships in order for them to comply with international regulations, federal laws, DOD Directives and Navy environmental protection regulations.  These regulations, laws and directives restrict the discharge of oily waste, sewage, solid waste, plastic waste, medical waste and hazardous waste.  Most of these applicable regulations require Navy ships to comply by fixed deadlines.  Failure to comply carries potential personal, civil, and criminal liability, and significantly imposes constraints on the operational capabilities of Navy ships.  In some instances, the compliance schedule has required an acceleration of the normal schedules in the procurement process.

SHORE BASED POLLUTION EQUIPMENT - (Logistics)
The shore based funds provide for equipment required to clean up Navy oil spills on the open sea as required by the Federal Water Pollution Control Act - Public Law 92-500.  The law created a National Oil and Hazardous Substance Pollution Contingency Plan, and designates the Department of Defense as one of the primary agencies responsible for promotion of effective operation of the plan.  The Supervisor of Salvage is assigned the responsibility to provide technical expertise, resources, and equipment for cleaning Navy-originated spills of oil and other hazardous material in coastal waters or the open sea.  Major items of procurement are:

[P40A / HF040 FIELD SUPPORT SYSTEMS]: These systems provide the auxiliary support required to keep Navy oil spill responders operating in the field without significant lapse of response time in all Navy Areas of Responsibility (AoR) according to Federal Law 33 CFR 155 and 154 and implemented by OPNAV5090.1D. As such, many Navy areas of operation are in remote and austere parts of the world with little to no operational support available, therefore the inventory objectives of equipment procured under this cost code are set to support emergency personnel in responding to the Navy's worst case oil or hazardous substance (OHS) discharge scenario in all AoR's and to be pre-positioned in the Emergency Ship Salvage Material (ESSM) Bases world-wide. Systems include Boom Handling Boats, Boom Tending Boats, Personnel Transfer Boats, Field Command & Control Centers, Field Conference Centers, Field Rigging Lockers, Field Repair Workshops, Personnel Berthing Modules, Field-grade Satellite Communications Systems, and Oil Spill Aerial Surveillance Systems. Unit cost varies greatly between systems.

[P40A / HF056 EQUIPMENT CLEAN-UP SYSTEMS]: These systems provide a full array of tools and materials required to perform the extensive decontamination needed for oil spill and hazardous chemical response equipment and personnel during an operation and prior to demobilization once a spill has been contained and recovered.

[P40A / HF057 OIL HANDLING SYSTEMS]: Oil handling systems provide the capability to recover and dispose of oil and debris during emergency oil spill response operations including temporary oil storage as required by 33 CFR 155 and 154. Equipment missions additionally include moving heavy oil or oil in cold conditions that exceed the capability of conventional skimmer systems and providing means of transferring oil from skimmers to temporary oil storage.  Systems include Vacuum Pump Systems, Oil Bladder Transfer Systems, Annular Water Injection Systems, At-Sea Bladder Pumping Systems, and Temporary Oil Storage Systems (Bladders, Tanks, etc.)These different systems can range greatly in individual unit cost.

[P40A / HF060 HOT TAP TRAINING SYSTEMS]: These systems are designed to train Fleet divers on the tools and techniques for penetrating into vessel oil tanks below the waterline.  The hot tap training kit is a system that contains a cutting device, an underwater hydraulic drill to drive the cutting mechanism and all necessary flanges, fasteners, valves, pumps and ancillaries to use when tapping through shell plating into laden tanks to remove the contents.  This training is required as a part of pre-deployment salvage preparations for Mobile Diving and Salvage Unit (MDSU) Companies to train for lightering or removal of oil from a vessel in distress.

[P40A / HF063 VESSEL OF OPPORTUNITY SKIMMER SYSTEMS]: The Vessel of Opportunity Skimmer Systems are oil skimmers designed and packaged to be deployed aboard any vessel that is available during an emergency oil spill response operation with enough deck space to support the operating equipment.  These systems allow for mechanical recovery of oil on the water in situations where traditional skimmers may not be practical, such as far offshore or in inclement weather or high currents. These systems include all the ancillary support equipment required to maintain oil spill recovery operations onboard a vessel for an extended period of time. These systems are packaged in an 8 foot x 8 foot x 20 foot standard shipping container with an 8 foot x 8 foot x 8 foot support container.

[P40A / HF067 VESSEL SKIMMER SYSTEMS]: These systems are self-propelled skimmers designed for near-shore and low sea-state open ocean environments and are used in conjunction with oil containment boom for mechanical recovery of oil on the water. They are designed to be rapidly transportable to the scene of an oil spill.

[P40A / HF830 PRODUCTION ENGINEERING]: HF830 PRODUCTION ENGINEERING:  Air conditioning plant kit and software quality control, technical manual and complete conversion instruction revisions, technical reports based on investigative efforts of OEM quality assurance or obsolescence issues, and support equipment removal from inactive ships or other Navy assets.  Development of technical manuals, Planned Maintenance System (PMS), Provisioning Technical Documentation (PTD), Program Support Data (PSD) and allowance Parts List (APLs), engineering to manage procurement and material, and in support of design reviews.

[P3A / HF024 CFC-114 (R-114) AC CONVERSION]: HF024 - CFC CONVERSION PROGRAM The production of chlorofluorocarbon(CFC)-based refrigerants (including CFC-12 and CFC R-114) was prohibited after 31 DEC 95 by the Clean Air Act of 1990. Presidential Executive Order 13693 calls for federal agencies to " promote sustainable acquisition and procurement by ensuring that each of the following environmental performance and sustainability factors are included ... alternatives to ozone-depleting substances".  The Navy is currently dependent on CFC-based refrigerants for the mission-critical cooling of (1) vital electronics and weapon systems, (2) food and medical stowage, and (3) inhabited spaces aboard surface ships and submarines. To counter the immediate threat of production cessation on uninterrupted Fleet operations, DoD directed the Defense Logistics Agency to establish a stockpile of CFC-based refrigerants. The stockpile was sized to support Fleet operations until the last CFC-based systems are retired or converted to ozone-friendly refrigerants. This program procures and installs conversion kits on existing CFC R-114 Air-Conditioning (A/C) plants onboard surface ships. The inventory objective for CFC R-114 is 402 converted units.

[P3A / HF024 CFC-114 (R-114) AC CONVERSION]: HF5IN - INSTALLATION OF EQUIPMENT - EXPEDITIONARY WARFARE
Funding is for installation of equipment for the Fleet Modernization Program installations.

HF6IN - INSTALLATION OF EQUIPMENT - SURFACE WARFARE
Funding is for installation of equipment for the Fleet Modernization Program installations.

[P3A - 2 / HF031 OPA IMPROVEMENTS]: Oil Pollution Abatement (OPA) Systems Improvements: Existing OPA systems have demonstrated poor operational availability, maintainability, and reliability. This comprehensive effort addresses the entire OPA system, from holding tanks to overboard discharge, leveraging recommended improvements new to the Fleet and approved, partially completed alterations. The alterations needed to correct design deficiencies are ship specific and require ship checks to confirm the current configuration as prior alterations may have completed one or several of the recommended improvements. The alterations may include, but are not limited to: installation of new tank level sensors; upgrades to the Oily Water Separator (OWS) and the Oil Content Monitor (OCM), correction of OWS suction problems, correction of OCM inlet & outlet piping including related of flush water piping configuration problems, and upgrade of oily waste transfer pump relief valve. Extensive work will occur with LHD-1 Class upgrades to convert the existing OWS to the VS-50 OWS and DDG-51 through DDG-88 ships will receive the Oily Waste Membrane System to produce an effluent that meets the 15 ppm maximum oil discharge requirement.

[P3A - 3 / HF031 DRY WASTE PROCESSING SUITE IMPROVEMENTS]: Dry Waste Processing Suite Improvements: The Fleet's challenged to keep solid waste equipment operating and sanitary. The root cause of this is: 1) workload; 2) reliability; 3) the maintainability (parts availability); and 4) obsolescence. The improvement and application of current and new processing tools will ensure the safe and efficient management of these materials. The goal is to decrease labor-hours by improving operation and maintenance, increase system availability and address all current and projected obsolescence issues and reducing parts failures by redesign.  Impacted equipment includes Compress Melt Units (CMUs), pulpers, shredders, incinerators, and compactors.

Justification.val: The FY 18 House Appropriation Committee (HAC) mark reduced Pollution Control Equipment FY 18 budget by $1,729K. Specifically, the mark reduced Shore Based Pollution Equipment - Equipment Clean Up Systems budget by $310K, Oil Pollution Abatement (OPA) Improvements budget by $1,361K, and Pollution Control Equipment Field Changes - Air Warfare budget by $58K.  FY19-FY20 increase of $3,027K is for continued ramp up of Oil Pollution Abatement System Improvement installations across Surface Warfare Class and Expeditionary Warfare Class ships.

Name.@footnote: HF040:  Unit costs vary greatly between various field support systems. Systems include containerized Field Command Centers, Field Repair Workshops, Field Rigging Lockers, Personnel Berthing Modules, Satellite Communication Systems, and Aerial Oil Surveillance Systems.  Unit costs vary greatly between various field support systems used to sustain oil spill response operations in remote and austere environments because these systems are all purpose-built and range from satellite communications equipment to Field Command & Control Centers, Field Repair Workshops, Field Rigging Lockers, Personnel Berthing Modules and Aerial Oil Surveillance Systems.
HF063:  Procurement of next generation Vessel of Opportunity Skimmer system with increased unit cost due to technology advancements commences in FY24.
Name.val: 1.5) HF063 VESSEL OF OPPORTUNITY SKIMMER SYSTEMS
4.1) HF031 POLLUTION CONTROL EQUIPMENT FIELD CHANGES

Name.@footnote: Installation cost per unit varies as a result of installation location (East versus West Coast), the type of Ship being converted (Expeditionary Warfare versus Surface Warfare), and number of units being converted (2-4 units per ship). Specifically in FY18, the cost to install DDG-70 increased when the original planned installation location changed from San Diego shifted to Pearl Harbor.  Installation costs also include Design Services Allocations (DSA) and Advanced Planning (AP) efforts which are funded one year prior to installation. In FY19, the cost includes DSA and AP efforts at $649K for six (6) units.

ImplementationMethodName.val: AIT:: Installation Name: HF024 CFC-114 (R-114) AC CONVERSION

Description.val:
The Navy is currently dependent on CFC-based refrigerants for the mission-critical cooling of (1) vital electronics and weapon systems, (2) food and medical stowage, and (3) inhabited spaces aboard surface ships and submarines.  To counter the immediate threat of production cessation on uninterrupted Fleet operations, DoD directed the Defense Logistics Agency to establish a stockpile of CFC-based refrigerants.  The stockpile was sized to support Fleet operations until the last CFC-based systems are retired or converted to ozone-friendly refrigerants.   This program procures and installs conversion kits on existing CFC R-114 Air-Conditioning (A/C) plants onboard surface ships.  The inventory objective for CFC R-114 is 402 converted units.

[HF024 CFC-114 (R-114) AC CONVERSION] Average cost per unit in PY is lower than FY18-FY20 in part as result of utilization of reclaimed parts and equipment. The FY19-FY20 hardware procurement costs are higher than FY18 due to new FY19 contract award escalation. 

The Program currently utilizes reclaimed equipment with cost avoidance in excess of $200,000 per unit.  The supply of reclaimed equipment was exhausted in FY17; as a result, the FY18AF equipment procurement unit cost exceeds standard inflation costs due to the unavailability of reclaimed parts.

Name.@footnote: Installation cost variance is due to the scope of the hardware suite and the installation location.  Installation costs include Design Services Allocations (DSA) and Advanced Planning (AP) efforts which are funded one year prior to installation.   FY18 installation funding supports: one (1) LHD-1 Class (SCD 13325) installation (in Norfolk) at $2,960K and five (5) ship DSA and AP efforts at $979K (DSA and AP costs in FY18 will range from $50K for a LPD-17 class (SCD 13326) to $530K for a LHD-1 class (SCD 13325)).   FY19 installation funding will support: two (2) CG-47 class (SCD 13323) installations (one in Mayport and one in Norfolk) at $1,113K per installation, one (1) LHD-1 Class (SCD 13325) installation (in Norfolk) at $3,020K, and one (1) LSD-41 class (SCD 13336) installations (in San Diego) at $803K; and seven (7) ship DSA and AP efforts at $1,031K (DSA and AP costs in FY19 will range from $5K for a LHA-6 class (SCD 84365) to $530K for a LHD-1 class (SCD 13325)).  LPD-17 Class FY19 availability was cancelled and deferred to FY25.
HF031 OPA Improvements Manufacturer Identification is a hardware suite and includes various part pieces and equipment procurements from multiple vendors per specific ship requirements.

ImplementationMethodName.val: AIT:: Installation Name: HF031 OPA Improvements

Description.val:
HF031 Expeditionary Warfare: OPA Systems Improvements: These installations resolve issues with existing OPA systems including poor operational availability, maintainability, and reliability. Variations in costs are subject to specific ship needs and are confirmed based upon ship checks. Shipset install/hardware buys may include: VS-50 oily water separators, secondary membrane treatment system, oil content monitor datalogger(s), multiple pumps, valves, valve actuators, sensors, switches, placards, and hoses.

HF031 Surface Warfare: OPA Systems Improvements: These installations resolve issues with existing OPA systems including poor operational availability, maintainability, and reliability. Variations in costs are subject to specific ship needs and are confirmed based upon ship checks. Shipset install/hardware buys may include: oily water transfer systems, secondary membrane treatment system, oil content monitor datalogger(s), multiple pumps, valves, valve actuators, sensors, switches, placards, and hoses.

[HF031 OPA Improvements] Hardware funding includes Production Engineering (PE) efforts. Significant hardware suite cost variance is due to specific ship requirements.  Each ship may require one or more of these improvements: datalogger, upgrades to oily waste transfer system, upgrades to primary treatment system, and upgrades to secondary treatment system.  
FY18 hardware funding supports: one (1) CG-47 class (SCD 13323) (in Norfolk) at $506K, one (1) LHD-1 Class (SCD 13325) (in Norfolk) at $1,575K, one (1) LPD-17 class (SCD 13326) (in Mayport) at $125K, and one (1) LSD-41 class (SCD 13336) (in San Diego) at $285K.
FY19 hardware funding will support: two (2) CG-47 class (SCD 13323) (one in Norfolk and one in San Diego) at $517K per suite, one (1) LHD-1 Class (SCD 13325) (in San Diego) at $1,687K, two (2) LHA-6 class (SCD 84365) (one in Norfolk and one in San Diego) at $16K per suite, and one (1) LPD-21 class (SCD 84365) (in San Diego) at $32K. LPD-17 Class FY19 hardware was deferred to FY24 to meet FY25 availability requirements.

ImplementationMethodName.val: AIT:: Installation Name: Dry Waste Processing Suite Improvements

Description.val:
Dry Waste Processing Suite Improvements:  Expeditionary Warfare: Funding provided to support dry waste handling equipment improvements on LHA, LHD, LPD and LSD platforms including compressed melt units, pulpers, shredders, and compactors.

Dry Waste Processing Suite Improvements:  Air Warfare: Funding provided to support dry waste handling equipment improvements on CVN platforms including compressed melt units, pulpers, shredders, incinerators, and compactors.
